This is an amended executive summary.  It reflects changes from the closure of Huntsman Polymers Odessa's Line 1 in the Polypropylene Plant.  All chemicals in the Line 1 inventory were removed as of February 2003.  This resulted in the reduction of the total chemicals in Process 2, Polypropylene.  This reduction of chemicals included the elimination Hydrogen Chloride, which was a toxic alternative release.

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies: Huntsman Polymers Odessa is committed to providing a safe, healthy, and environmentally conscious work place for its employees and neighbors.  This is exemplified by Huntsman Odessa having earned OSHA VPP STAR status and ISO 14001 certification.  The Huntsman Odessa facility maintains a working PSM program, which implements a series of steps to prevent potential hazards associated with the process and assures a well-trained workforce.  The PSM program further implements its policies with onsite procedures and manuals.  Huntsman Polymers Odessa participates with community agencies to develop emergency response plans and participates in cooperative training with these agencies.  Since its certification in January 1993, the Odessa Site has been an active participant in the International Standards Organization (ISO) 9002 quality management program.

2. Regulated Substances: Huntsman Polymers Odessa is located in Odessa, Texas.  The Odessa site operates five Program Level 3 processes.  These processes receive, handle, and store flammable hydrocarbon feedstocks for the production of olefins and specialty grade polymers.  End uses include medical and personal care products, electronic cable coatings, adhesives and sealants, as well as boat and vehicle trims.  Huntsman's Odessa site has large volumes of several regulated flammable substances, such as ethane, ethylene, propane, propylene, butane, and butene.  The Odessa site uses small volumes of toxic chemicals, which are consumed in the process.  The toxi

c chemicals are:
- Chlorine - Used for water treatment.
- Vinyl Acetate - Used as a comonomer in the manufacturing of polyethylene.

3. Offsite Consequence Analysis: The RMP Rule requires offsite consequence analysis (OCA) to be performed to estimate the potential for an accidental release of a regulated substance to affect the public or the environment.  This OCA includes the development of worst and alternantive release scenarios for the release of toxic and flammable substances.  The OCA allows for the consideration of administrative controls in estimating potential scenario impacts.  Distances for worst case and alternative release scenarios in this RMP have been calculated using the methods described in EPA's OCA Guidance Document.  The population within the circles defined by these distances have been calculated using the Landview III program.  For release scenarios where there are no public residences inside the circle, the reported population is zero.

WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The worst case scenarios, based upon EPA required assumptions, are highly unlikely and have not occurred at this facility. 

The worst case scenario associated with the release of flammable substances is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE), involving an underground hydrocarbon storage well.

The worst case scenario associated with the release of a toxic substance is a chlorine vapor release from a chlorine cylinder.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The alternative case scenarios used in this RMP do not take into account existing safety systems and process controls, thus making them extremely liberal.  The one active mitigation considered is the manual isolation of releases after 10 to 20 minutes.  

The alternantive case scenario for flammable substances is a complete seal failure on the LPG Pump (P-55C) in the Utilities Area.  

The alternative case scenario for chlorine is a vapor release from a failure of the 3/8 inch tubing off of a cylinder of chlorine.

The alternative case scenari

o for vinyl acetate is a pump seal failure on the pump used for unloading vinyl acetate from a truck into a storage area. 

4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps: Following is a brief summary of the elements that Huntsman's Odessa Site has implemented to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements outlined by EPA as well as with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Huntsman's Odessa site maintains a compilation of current and accurate written safety information to identify and understand the hazards of the process.  This includes information pertaining to:
- Hazards of regulated substances: For each regulated substance, there is a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS).
- The technology of the process: Includes a discussion of process chemistry, safe upper and lower limits of temperature and pressure, and analysis of consequences of deviation.
- Equipment in the process: Includes such information as materials of construction, diagrams of the piping and instrumentation, safety systems, and design codes.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

Huntsman's Odessa site has performed a process hazard analysis on each process to identify potential hazards, adequacy of the engineering and administrative controls, and ways to minimize those hazards.  Huntsman Odessa utilizes the HAZOP  and What-if/Checklist methodologies, recognized and generally accepted methods for identifying and evalualting hazards in the process.  The Odessa site assigns associates to the HAZOP team who are knowledgeable in the HAZOP methodology and the specific process.  The HAZOP team develops recommendations to reduce the potential hazards which, if approved, are implemented within a reasonable period of time.

OPERATING PROCEDURES

Huntsman Odessa maintains written operating procedures that were developed with the operators to provide clear instruction for safely c

onducting activities associated with a covered process.  The procedures address steps for all operating phases, safety systems, control measures and precautions to prevent exposures to process hazards.  The procedures are reviewed and revised periodically to ensure their accuracy and completeness.

TRAINING

Huntsman Odessa provides initial training as well as refresher training to associates to assure the required level of skills and knowledge are maintained.  The training emphasizes safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  All operators receive refresher training at least annually.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

Huntsman Odessa has developed written procedures for maintaining the operating components of the process (including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown system controls, and pumps) through the mechanical integrity program.  The program is comprised of well-trained personnel who follow maintenance, testing, and inspection procedures that ensure proper function of process equipment.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Huntsman Odessa has established and implemented written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and any changes to the facility that affect a covered process.  The procedures assure that prior to any change, the following issues are considered: the technical basis for the proposed change, its impact on safety, health, and the environment, any modifications to operating procedures, the necessary time period for the change, and any authorization requirements.  Associates involved in operating a process, as well as maintenance and contract associates whose job will be affected, are informed of and trained in the change.  If necessary, the process safety information and operating procedures are updated.

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

Huntsman Odessa performs pre-startup safety reviews when the addition of or a modification to the facility

other elements of the process safety management program.  Huntsman Odessa ensures all associates have access to PHA's and all other process safety management information.

HOT WORK PERMIT

Huntsman Odessa employs a hot work permit program for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.  If any hot work is performed near a covered process, a hot work permit is issued that documents fire prevention and protection requirements for the operation, dates and times authorized for the hot work, and object on which the work is to be performed.  Hot work permits are kept on file until the work is complete.  

CONTRACTORS

Huntsman Odessa has developed procedures and policies for selecting and ensuring contractors are competent,  knowledgeable and can safely perform their work.  Huntsman Odessa provides information to them about hazards associated with their work environment and has developed appropriate safe work practices.  Huntsman Odessa also evaluates the safety programs and performances of contractors as a part of their continued employement. 

5. Five Year Accident History: Huntsman Odessa has one accidental release to report for the five-year accident history.  On October 31, 2001, an ethylene/propane release resulted in one on-site injury.  There was no fire, explosion, or property damage.  There were no off-site consequences resulting in deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter-in-place warnings, property damage, or environmental impact. 

6. Emergency Response Program:  Huntsman Odessa has a written emergency response program that contains procedures to be followed in case of an accidental release.  These procedures include steps for informing local emergency response agencies and the public.  In addition, Huntsman Odessa provides training to its emergency response associates and to local emergency responders who may be called upon to assist in emergency response. is made that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review confirms, prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals, that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications: safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; management of change requirements are met; and training of associates affected by the modification is complete.

COMPLIANCE AUDIT

Huntsman Odessa performs audits of its compliance with provisions of its process safety management program.  Teams comprised of associates, with appropriate knowledge of audit techniques, process safety and operating experience, conduct audits every three years to verify the procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.  The findings of the audit team are reviewed and tracked until resolved.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Huntsman Odessa investigates any incidents that resulted in, or could possibly have resulted in, a catastrophic release of covered chemicals.  The investigation is promptly conducted, commencing within 48 hours of any incident.  To perform the investigation, Huntsman Odessa utilizes a team consiting of persons with the appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.  A report is prepared at the conclusion of the incident investigation that address the incident, the factors that contributed to it, and recommendations resulting from the investigation.  Huntsman Odessa establishhed a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings, recommendations, and to document their resolution.  Finally, incident reports are reviewed with all affected personnel.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Huntsman Odessa has developed a written action plan for associate participation in all aspects of its process safety management program.  Huntsman Odessa consults with associates on the conduction and development of PHA's and on development of the

EPC) to develop emergency response procedures that identify resources, chemicals, contracts, and material safety data sheets for participating companies.  Other community activities include cooperative training between the Odessa site and the Odessa Fire Department, as well as making available equipment, technical information, personnel, and supplies for county mutual aid.  The emergency response management plan and its procedures are reveiwed periodically and updated as necessary.  Likewise, the emergency response equipment is maintained, tested, and inspected periodically.

7. Planned changes to improve safety:  Huntsman Odessa has an on-going commitment to improve safety, health, and to protect the environment.  In addition to frequently scheduled internal company audits and inspections, the site undergoes an annual self-evaluation as part of the American Chemistry Council (ACC) Responsible Care process safety codes and OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).  Improving safety is a continuing process at Huntsman, and a number of significant safety improvements have been made.  Recent safety improvements include:

- Routing additional Pressure Safety Valves to a flare system.
- Installation of additional gas detection systems.
- Installation of distributed control systems.
- Installiation of additional automatic emergency isolation valves. 

The following safety, health, and environmental improvements are anticipated during the next five years:

- Addition of a pressurized brine system for the underground hydrocarbon storage wells.
- Upgrade of additional pumps in the Olefin area to tandem seal design.
- Upgrade of exisiting flare system.
- Installation of new flare system at Polyethylene Plant.
- Installation of a RTO unit in Polyethylene. 
- Improvements to the fire water distribution system.
- Upgrades to existing fire fighting equipment.
- Joint venture to build a new fire training field with local Junior College and Odessa Fire Dpeartment.
